conclusion: Key physical relation: A conductor of length L moving with speed v perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field B develops an emf E = B L v.
In the present geometry, the length across which the emf is measured is the inside diameter d of the pipe, so L = d.
The average speed of the liquid v equals v = E / (B d).
The volume flow rate Q is the product of speed and the pipe’s cross-sectional area A.
The cross-sectional area A = π d² /4.
Q = A v = (π d² /4) · [ E /( B d ) ] = π d E /( 4 B).
Flow rate of the conductive liquid: Q = (π d E) / (4 B).
